\emph{Bounding the diameter.} The diameter bound follows directly from Lemma \ref{lem:diam2graphs}: (since $0 \leq q\leq p$) with probability at least \(1 - n^2 e^{-q^2(n-1)}\), the diameter of \(G\) is at most \(2\). To see the diameter bound, note that any edge in $G$ occurs independently with probability at least $q>0$. Hence, the probability that any two $u,v\in V, u\neq v,$ have distance greater than $2$ is the probability that they do not share an edge and have no common neighbor which is $\geq(1-q) \cdot (1-q^2)^{n-2}$. By a union bound over all pairs of vertices:
$$\mathbb{P}[\gdiam(G)> 2] \leq \binom{n}{2}(1-q) \cdot (1-q^2)^{n-2}\leq \exp\left( 2\ln n + \ln\frac{1}{1-q} - (n-2)\ln\frac{1}{1-q^2}\right)   \exp(- \Theta(n)).$$
